content.webTitle: Premier League: Arsenal's manager, Arsène Wenger, says Guus Hiddink cannot manage both Russia and Chelsea in the long term

fields.headline: Hiddink cannot combine two jobs permanently, says Wenger
fields.bodyText: Arsène Wenger has said it is "impossible" for Chelsea's head coach, Guus Hiddink, to combine duties at Stamford Bridge with the Russia national team job permanently. "I believe it is impossible to take on a club and country role permanently but in the short term he can do it," the Arsenal manager said. "Russia have only two minor games which he can deal with in the international break – against Azerbaijan and Liechtenstein – but long-term it's not realistic. "It's a special situation anyway with Hiddink because of his close connections with Russia and [Chelsea owner Roman] Abramovich." Wenger, who also said he was surprised at the sacking last week of Luiz Felipe Scolari though it might have been related to the "atmosphere around the club", is confident that Hiddink will make an immediate impact in west London. "I rate Guus Hiddink highly. He has been tremendously successful everywhere and is a big personality. But you know with Chelsea what to expect – one super manager to leave and another to come in."
